titleInfo.subTitle: Harold V. Andersen oral history interview, 1999

name.description: "Harold V. Anderson was born in 1907 outside of Cumberland, Iowa. His father, Perry, a cattle buyer, and mother, Pauline, moved the family to Yuma, Colorado, around 1910. Andersen started high school in Yuma in 1921 and graduated in 1925. He attended the University of Denver for one year on a scholarship, but could not afford to continue his studies there. Throughout the 1920s and '30s, Andersen continued his education at various institutions (when funding allowed) and held multiple jobs, working as a carpenter, lab supervisor, and field archaeologist to name a few. While working in a coal mine in Utah in 1927, he lost half of his thumb in an accident. He earned a B.A. in Geology from the University of Nebraska in 1940 and soon took a job with the Alabama Geological Survey. He enlisted in the Army Corps of Engineers during World War II in 1942 and served briefly in Europe. His engineering unit was sent back to California to train for the invasion of Japan, but the war ended before they were deployed. He was discharged in 1946 after achieving the rank of captain. A visit to Louisiana State University that same year led to a graduate assistantship in their burgeoning Geology Department. His dissertation research, completed in tandem with another student, James Morgan, focused on a foraminiferal assemblage found in mud lump clays from the Mississippi River. In 1950, four months after receiving his Ph.D., he was recalled to military duty during the Korean War. He spent the next two years working on a technical manual called ""Geology and Its Military Application."" After his service, he returned to teaching at LSU and retired in 1977 as Professor Emeritus of the Geology and Geophysics Department. Andersen passed away on June 28, 2000 at age 92."
